text: ਰਾਗੁ ਗੋਂਡ ਬਾਣੀ ਕਬੀਰ ਜੀਉ ਕੀ ਘਰੁ ੨
section: Gond - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Raag Gond, The Word Of Kabeer Jee, Second House:

transliteration.text: rāg gōnhd bānī kabīr jīu kī ghar 2

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

section: Gond - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

section: Gond - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: They tied my arms, bundled me up, and threw me before an elephant.

melody.description: Gond is an expression of triumph, however these feelings are balanced and in perspective ensuring that there is also an aspect of humility. Therefore, although there is a sense of knowing and understanding the achievement, there is not a feeling of becoming obsessed or getting lost in the achievement itself.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Gond - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The elephant driver struck him on the head, and infuriated him.

melody.description: Gond is an expression of triumph, however these feelings are balanced and in perspective ensuring that there is also an aspect of humility. Therefore, although there is a sense of knowing and understanding the achievement, there is not a feeling of becoming obsessed or getting lost in the achievement itself.

section: Gond - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: But the elephant ran away, trumpeting,

section: Gond - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I am a sacrifice to this image of the Lord.||1||

melody.description: Gond is an expression of triumph, however these feelings are balanced and in perspective ensuring that there is also an aspect of humility. translation.text: O my Lord and Master, You are my strength.

melody.description: Gond is an expression of triumph, however these feelings are balanced and in perspective ensuring that there is also an aspect of humility. section: Gond - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The Qazi shouted at the driver to drive the elephant on. ||1||Pause||

melody.description: Gond is an expression of triumph, however these feelings are balanced and in perspective ensuring that there is also an aspect of humility. translation.text: He yelled out, "O driver, I shall cut you into pieces.

translation.text: Hit him, and drive him on!"

section: Gond - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: But the elephant did not move; instead, he began to meditate.

melody.description: Gond is an expression of triumph, however these feelings are balanced and in perspective ensuring that there is also an aspect of humility. translation.text: The Lord God abides within his mind. ||2||

translation.text: that you have made him into a bundle and thrown him before the elephant?

translation.text: The Qazi could not understand it; he was blind. ||3||

translation.text: Says Kabeer, such is my Lord and Master.

text: ਚਉਥੇ ਪਦ ਮਹਿ ਜਨ ਕੀ ਜਿੰਦੁ ॥੪॥੧॥੪॥
section: Gond - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The soul of His humble servant dwells in the fourth state. ||4||1||4||

transliteration.text: chauthē pad mah jan kī jind .4.1.4.

melody.description: Gond is an expression of triumph, however these feelings are balanced and in perspective ensuring that there is also an aspect of humility. Therefore, although there is a sense of knowing and understanding the achievement, there is not a feeling of becoming obsessed or getting lost in the achievement itself.
